author: zhunsak
title: Self-Hosted Full Node for End Users
description: A strong community of users running full nodes is pivotal to the security/trust of a protocol. It should be easy and simple for users to verify their own transactions.

f6_assessments.q0: A self-hosted full node is inherently more secure for the end-user. Daedalus runs a full node in the background and requires substantial processing power to run smoothly. The recommended hardware for Daedalus is now a 64-bit Dual-core processor, RAM: 16GB, Drive space: 100 - 200GB and Broadband Internet connection. The large number of mini computers like Intel NUK with can run i7 processor support running of Danelus in a smooth manner. The proposal is to identify low-power, reliable, and cheap hardware which can host cardano full node. This part of the proposal is clear but the capability and the compatibility of available commercial off-the-shelf hardware are well known and the need for identification is just personal research, The second part is to fully open-source project that has a web-UI to manage, connect to, and run a Cardano node. This again is a duplication of effort since there are tools available to run the Cardano node using web UI even if it is difficult to install it as a matter of configuration. Therefore I could not see any critical issue that is being address in this proposal.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer has worked as a Java software developer, A Linux Systems Administrator, and a cybersecurity engineer. He has provided his Github profile with 16 repositories and linkedin profile. He is about 14 years of experience in software development and has good academic qualifications in security and software engineering. With these capabilities and credentials, the proposer can be assessed to be capable of building the proposal in a successful manner. The proposal has minimal technical risks and a person with Java development experience should be able to implement the proposal successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: The plan presented is detailed and the tasks have been identified. The budget breakdown is not detailed. The total cost of the project is 180000 out of which 20000 USD is for buying much low-cost hardware for experimentation and 160000 as the payment of the proposer for 12  months which is about 13000USD per month. Out of the twelve months, the proposal has earmarked 2 months for researching the best frontend framework or tool to build the web application. The experienced person is expected to select the framework based on his experience and allotting 2 months and 26K USD for this seems unreasonable. The time frame is extended and with no references to past work, it is difficult to establish the auditability. Overall the proposal is looking quite expensive with very little value addition to the Cardano ecosystem.

f6_assessments.q0: One of the main goals of Cardano is decentralization, and with the ever growing network of Cardano, it's going to be challenging and hard for new comers to setup a full node. Thus this proposal would certainly attract new members to join in the Cardano network as its low cost and simple. With more nodes running, the more secure Cardano would be and as mentioned in the proposal, this will make hydra highly scalable which is very beneficial to Cardano. Thus, I believe this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: There is a roadmap listed in the proposal, which is just sufficient. However as for the budget breakdown, the cost is a little on the high side. I would prefer if the proposal allocated more on the hardware side or maybe hire another resources to help accomplished the project. The team consists of 1 member, and the proposal is lacking the information regarding the track record or CV of the member. More information regarding that would be appreciated. There are risk listed in the proposal and its a valid risk. As the timeline is rather long (close to a year) and the lack of resources to develop the project, I have to stand neutral in this proposal's feasibility.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal has key milestones and deliverables listed and would be trackable via the Github Repo. But would appreciate if the author did list more channels to communicate with the community (i.e Twitter, Discord etc). There are KPI/Metric listed to quantify the success of the project, but it's rather brief. More detail on the KPI/Metric would be good. All in all, I have nothing else to add and stand neutral in the auditability of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: The "self-hosted fill node for end users" proposal addresses the dapps, products & integration very well. The proposer will build a small appliance to make running Cardano node at home possible. He raises the example of umbrel done for bitcoin. The solution can be low cost, cross platform and  powerful enough to run a full node. He will also connect with major wallets in documentation for the integration. Also the security and privacy would be at the top of his agenda while he integrates the login with wallets.  The solution will promote decentralization. The more node run by the community, it will also improve security and prevent the attack. It will be an interesting hardware (product) that will boost Cardano adoption. It has the potential for future scale as a full node to run hydra heads on with ease. Although the risk for this project is personal as the time and funding. The proposer also justifies his project's high price tag with the rejected job offer.
f6_assessments.q1: The project will take 1 year and it will involve around sourcing the machine to run the system,  build the optimized version of Cardano node, build a spock rest APO, research the best frontend framework and build the web application frontend and test for security feature. The budget are splitted only 2 main parts as the purchase of equipments and the paycheck for the job he would reject for 1 year during the bear market. The proposer is very upfront with the genuine personal reason that he wants to work remote so he declined job offer. It would be good to have a proof of offer although I acknowledge that this could be confidential. However, this might prove his point and improve transparency.  He doesn't plan to return for funding but will set up the donate page on github that goes back to Catalyst project.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer views the success of this proposal as having a software package and list of machines that can best be used to install the software package with clear documentation. Maybe he would like to explain on post hardware development plan e.g. how he intend to sell his low-cost box that runs the software and allows users to manage their own full Cardano node. It will be interesting project that will garner the interest of community. The project progress and update can be monitored by the community via github and please consider provide the links in your proposal for easy project tracking.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal seeks funding for the creation of a small appliance that will make running a Cardano full node possible for the non expert end user.
The problem is clearly stated, it is pivotal for the security of a protocol, that users are running full nodes.
The solution is a simple ready to use appliance that will not require significant expertise to run at home. The whole product will be open sourced.
The impact of this proposal is clear for the strength and therefore for the future of Cardano.
This proposal is in line with the Dapps, Products & Integrations goals and metrics.
I strongly agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer speaks in clear terms of the idea and the steps needed to be taken for the project to be completed. 
The proposer envisions a risk of time and funding, stating that the proposer rejects a FAANG offer and will quit full time job but has to provide for his family.
The voter should know that currently the funding of Catalyst is USD denominated and released in fractions once every month if progress reports are submitted. That means I see no issue there.
The proposer provides a detailed plan by months for the different components of the project. 
The budget asked is divided in two sections, 160K for employment remuneration for the proposer and 20K for the purchase of hardware and software to be experimented on.
The proposer states that he is the main driver for this project, however since the project is open source, he will be happy to take commits from the community.
The proposal itself does not hold any information for the proposer, however in the comments, the community reminded the proposer to provide credentials and the proposer provided linkedin link https://www.linkedin.com/in/cardanerd/ and a github repository with small part of his work.
The proposer is member of ideascale since 12 jun 2021 and has six comments since then. The proposer is also a Cardano ambassador according to linkedin profile.
The proposer does not intend to return to Catalyst for funding for this project.
I strongly agree that it is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
Auditability will be trough commits in github, since this is an open source project and the community will have access to the github repository I imagine it will be easy to follow the progress of the project and compare it to the timeline listed in the plan of the proposal.
Success metrics are clearly defined and will be delivered at the end of the project.
I strongly agree that this proposal provides me with sufficient information to assess the progress in attaining its stated goals.

f6_assessments.q0:
Beginning this assessment with the problem statement, we start from the assertion that individual users capable of running full nodes are crucial in order to safeguard the security and the trust of the Cardano ecosystem. The value proposition is to build an open source solution able to manage a Cardano node. The proposal also includes the example of umbrel, a solution that allows users to run their own Bitcoin / Lightning nodes on easy to source hardware. 

I appreciate the initiative, and I believe that the ecosystem needs a wide array of software and hardware solutions that can increase decentralization and allow home users to independently run their own nodes on a multitude of software and hardware combinations. And since the solution will be open source, the entire community can benefit from such a project.
f6_assessments.q1:
Zachary, our proposer, is a software developer and cybersecurity engineer. A very weak point of this proposal is that he wishes to do the entire project himself, over the course of a year. That is an approach that comes with many downsides and risks, out of which I mention: loss of motivation over the course of the project, chance in personal circumstances, or other situations outside his control. So while I applaud his good intentions I draw a very significant red flag in this area, and would appreciate it if the next iterations of the project, if any, try to gather at least a small team around the idea.

Timewise, the project would take roughly one year to complete, since Zachary would devote full time to this project if the proposal were to be funded. He would start with researching suitable machines for running the system, build a nix derivation of the cardano node and test it, then move on to an API solution, then building the front end application and finally test the solution during the last month. 

The budget is very simple to understand. 20k USD would go towards acquiring single board computers for testing, but there is no additional split of this caption to understand exactly which devices he would purchase (besides the mac mini which is offered as an example). The rest of the budget, 160k USD, would go towards paying himself during this one year period. Even if it were a single person project, I would have appreciated seeing a more detailed split of the budget, including an estimation of the hours necessary to build the solution as well as an hourly rate applicable for it.  

Considering the higher risks than normal given that we do not have a fully fledged team behind this proposal, as well as the very brief budget details, I think two stars are appropriate.
f6_assessments.q2:
Zachary offers as a project tracking solution the github commits, measured against the exact details of the proposal. Success, in his view, would imply that a software package along with a list of machines that can run it would be available at the end of the year, as well as clear documentation relevant.  

Being a rather straightforward project, I don’t see any reason why the Cardano community would not be able to keep track of this project, so I deem five stars as appropriate.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is for the development of an application that would make running a Cardano node easier for the everyday person.  Even easier than Daedalus.  This is important for Cardano because the more users running their own full node, the more secure and trustworthy the Cardano protocol is, which the proposer points out in the problem statement.  

The proposer plans to build and release this application via the bsd 3-clause license on GitHub.  This means the code will be open source for anyone to use, as long as you include bsd copyright and license in your new code, which will be useful for developers in the ecosystem.  The proposer also plans to build documentation for connecting each major wallet to a self hosted Cardano node using his application. This would help end users make full use of their self-hosted Cardano node.

Another reason this proposal is highly impactful to Cardano in the future is hydra heads will need to be run on full nodes and this solution will help make hydra even more scalable for Cardano by providing an easy way to run a dedicated full node.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer states they have experience as Java software developer, Linux Systems Administrator, and a cybersecurity engineer.  They also state they have received a job offer from one of the major FAANG companies and use this to justify their relatively high requested funds amount.   In the comment section of this proposal, they provide links to their Github and Linkedin profiles to back up their claims and show they do have a significant amount of development experience. Also, their use of technical language like “nix derivaton” and “single board computers” which is like a raspberry pi, indicates they do likely know what they’re talking about in this field.

It appears that $20,000 of the requested funds are going towards resources needed to develop this product while the rest of the $180,000 goes toward his salary so that he can work on this full time for a year. I understand why they would request this much, because this is similar to the salary of software engineers that work at FAANG companies. However, I feel this is a lot for one person to ask for upfront for a year’s worth of work.  I also understand that Catalyst only allows money to be asked for upfront, but I think this proposal would feel less risky if it was broken up over multiple catalyst funds.  Then more funding could be requested once some work has been proven.  I also would’ve liked to have seen a more detailed breakdown of how the amount of $20,000 was decided on, to help readers evaluate if it seems reasonable.

The proposer does provide a timeline that outlines the milestones they would like to achieve over the next year along with the number of months they expect each one to take.  This shows they have thought about the steps needed to be taken to be successful.

Given the experience of the proposer and the long timeline allocated for this proposal, I believe it is likely to be implemented successfully.  The only thing that makes me a little wary is that I feel like the amount of funds requested is a lot of money upfront to trust one person with for a whole year's work.
f6_assessments.q2: Since they plan to develop this product on a public GitHub repository, the public can follow along as developments are made.  Progress on the GitHub can easily be tracked based on the commits made and checking if the key milestones from the roadmap are reached. These are things like the nix derivation being built and then tested on each OS.  There are no quantitative KPIs provided for tracking the success of this proposal for after this application is developed.  An example of a KPI that could’ve been provided is the number of users or number of downloads of the application.  All things considered, this proposal provides a sufficient amount of information for tracking the progress of development, but no information for tracking the success of the project after development has finished.

solution: I will build a small appliance to make running your own Cardano at home possible, similar to what umbrel does for bitcoin. I will bulid a web interface and a way for apps to integrate with that app.
experience: I have worked as a Java software developer, A linux Systems Administrator, and as a cybersecurity engineer. I recently received a job offer to work for a FAANG company but then they rescinded the offer because I wanted to work remote. So, I'd rather build on Cardano in a bear.
